gw.api.web

Class Scopes

  • java.lang.Object
    • gw.api.web.Scopes

  • public class Scopes
extends Object
    Provides maps scoped to various lifespans within a web-server's environment. The maps are not strongly typed.

    A typical usage of a request variable with Scopes. Access to the variable is encapsulated in the MyClass.MyRequestVar property for ease of use. 

    // Assign a value to the request variable.
// This can be done early in the request, such as in a PCF page
MyClass.MyRequestVar = "hello"
// Access the request variable
// This could be done later, such as in rules or IPreUpdateHandler
print( MyClass.MyRequestVar )
class MyClass {
static var MY_REQUEST_VAR = "MyRequestVar"
static property get MyRequestVar() : String {
if ( Scopes.RequestAvailable ) {
return Scopes.Request.get( MY_REQUEST_VAR ) as String
} else {
return null
}
}
static property set MyRequestVar( value: String ) {
if ( Scopes.RequestAvailable ) {
Scopes.Request.put( MY_REQUEST_VAR, value )
}
}
}

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static Map<Object,Object> Application
      Returns a Map that can be used to store and retrieve values whose lifespan should be bound up with the lifespan of the web application. This is almost identical to static variables, but the map will be cleared when a servlet is torn down and restarted. Note This map is only available in execution contexts that are associated with a servlet container. If it is accessed in other contexts an IllegalStateException will be thrown. Also be aware that how this data is stored is dependent on the servlet container you are running in, and your data must satisfy any constraints put on the data by that container (e.g. it might be necessary to make your objects Serializable)
      static Map<Object,Object> Request
      Returns a Map that can be used to store and retrieve values whose lifespan should be bound up with the lifespan of the request. This map is not synchronized since multiple threads should not be able to get to the same request object Note This map is only available in execution contexts that are associated with a web request. If it is accessed in other contexts an IllegalStateException will be thrown. Call isRequestAvailable() to determine if this method is safe to use. Also be aware that how this data is stored is dependent on the servlet container you are running in, and your data must satisfy any constraints put on the data by that container (e.g. it might be necessary to make your objects Serializable)
      static boolean RequestAvailable
      Returns true if it is safe to call getRequest() and getSession(). Otherwise, those methods will throw an exception. Tests if there is an HTTP request in context. The absence of a request indicates there is nowhere to store the value of this variable. Sometimes it's useful to test for the request if it's possible to execute the enclosing code block in an environment that may not run within a request or session. For instance, some batch server environments execute independent of a request.
      static Map<Object,Object> Session
      Returns a Map that can be used to store and retrieve values whose lifespan should be bound up with the lifespan of the users session. This map is synchronized since multiple threads can access the session simultaneously (e.g. AJAX requests.) Note This map is only available in execution contexts that are associated with a web request. If it is accessed in other contexts an IllegalStateException will be thrown. Call isRequestAvailable() to determine if this method is safe to use. Also be aware that how this data is stored is dependent on the servlet container you are running in, and your data must satisfy any constraints put on the data by that container (e.g. it might be necessary to make your objects Serializable)

      • Fields inherited from class java.lang.Object

      static Map<Object,Object> getApplication()
      Returns a Map that can be used to store and retrieve values whose lifespan should be bound up with the lifespan of the web application. This is almost identical to static variables, but the map will be cleared when a servlet is torn down and restarted. Note This map is only available in execution contexts that are associated with a servlet container. If it is accessed in other contexts an IllegalStateException will be thrown. Also be aware that how this data is stored is dependent on the servlet container you are running in, and your data must satisfy any constraints put on the data by that container (e.g. it might be necessary to make your objects Serializable)
      static Map<Object,Object> getRequest()
      Returns a Map that can be used to store and retrieve values whose lifespan should be bound up with the lifespan of the request. This map is not synchronized since multiple threads should not be able to get to the same request object Note This map is only available in execution contexts that are associated with a web request. If it is accessed in other contexts an IllegalStateException will be thrown. Call isRequestAvailable() to determine if this method is safe to use. Also be aware that how this data is stored is dependent on the servlet container you are running in, and your data must satisfy any constraints put on the data by that container (e.g. it might be necessary to make your objects Serializable)
      static Map<Object,Object> getSession()
      Returns a Map that can be used to store and retrieve values whose lifespan should be bound up with the lifespan of the users session. This map is synchronized since multiple threads can access the session simultaneously (e.g. AJAX requests.) Note This map is only available in execution contexts that are associated with a web request. If it is accessed in other contexts an IllegalStateException will be thrown. Call isRequestAvailable() to determine if this method is safe to use. Also be aware that how this data is stored is dependent on the servlet container you are running in, and your data must satisfy any constraints put on the data by that container (e.g. it might be necessary to make your objects Serializable)
      static boolean isRequestAvailable()
      Returns true if it is safe to call getRequest() and getSession(). Otherwise, those methods will throw an exception. Tests if there is an HTTP request in context. The absence of a request indicates there is nowhere to store the value of this variable. Sometimes it's useful to test for the request if it's possible to execute the enclosing code block in an environment that may not run within a request or session. For instance, some batch server environments execute independent of a request.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        equals, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Field Detail

      • Application

        Map<Object,Object> Application

        Returns a Map that can be used to store and retrieve values whose lifespan should be bound up with the lifespan of the web application. This is almost identical to static variables, but the map will be cleared when a servlet is torn down and restarted.

        Note This map is only available in execution contexts that are associated with a servlet container. If it is accessed in other contexts an IllegalStateException will be thrown. Also be aware that how this data is stored is dependent on the servlet container you are running in, and your data must satisfy any constraints put on the data by that container (e.g. it might be necessary to make your objects Serializable)

      • Request

        Map<Object,Object> Request

        Returns a Map that can be used to store and retrieve values whose lifespan should be bound up with the lifespan of the request. This map is not synchronized since multiple threads should not be able to get to the same request object

        Note This map is only available in execution contexts that are associated with a web request. If it is accessed in other contexts an IllegalStateException will be thrown. Call isRequestAvailable() to determine if this method is safe to use. Also be aware that how this data is stored is dependent on the servlet container you are running in, and your data must satisfy any constraints put on the data by that container (e.g. it might be necessary to make your objects Serializable)

      • RequestAvailable

        boolean RequestAvailable
        Returns true if it is safe to call getRequest() and getSession(). Otherwise, those methods will throw an exception.

        Tests if there is an HTTP request in context. The absence of a request indicates there is nowhere to store the value of this variable. Sometimes it's useful to test for the request if it's possible to execute the enclosing code block in an environment that may not run within a request or session. For instance, some batch server environments execute independent of a request.

      • Session

        Map<Object,Object> Session

        Returns a Map that can be used to store and retrieve values whose lifespan should be bound up with the lifespan of the users session. This map is synchronized since multiple threads can access the session simultaneously (e.g. AJAX requests.)

        Note This map is only available in execution contexts that are associated with a web request. If it is accessed in other contexts an IllegalStateException will be thrown. Call isRequestAvailable() to determine if this method is safe to use. Also be aware that how this data is stored is dependent on the servlet container you are running in, and your data must satisfy any constraints put on the data by that container (e.g. it might be necessary to make your objects Serializable)

      • getRequest

        Map<Object,Object> getRequest()

        Returns a Map that can be used to store and retrieve values whose lifespan should be bound up with the lifespan of the request. This map is not synchronized since multiple threads should not be able to get to the same request object

        Note This map is only available in execution contexts that are associated with a web request. If it is accessed in other contexts an IllegalStateException will be thrown. Call isRequestAvailable() to determine if this method is safe to use. Also be aware that how this data is stored is dependent on the servlet container you are running in, and your data must satisfy any constraints put on the data by that container (e.g. it might be necessary to make your objects Serializable)

      • getSession

        Map<Object,Object> getSession()

        Returns a Map that can be used to store and retrieve values whose lifespan should be bound up with the lifespan of the users session. This map is synchronized since multiple threads can access the session simultaneously (e.g. AJAX requests.)

        Note This map is only available in execution contexts that are associated with a web request. If it is accessed in other contexts an IllegalStateException will be thrown. Call isRequestAvailable() to determine if this method is safe to use. Also be aware that how this data is stored is dependent on the servlet container you are running in, and your data must satisfy any constraints put on the data by that container (e.g. it might be necessary to make your objects Serializable)

        Returns:

      • isRequestAvailable

        boolean isRequestAvailable()
        Returns true if it is safe to call getRequest() and getSession(). Otherwise, those methods will throw an exception.

        Tests if there is an HTTP request in context. The absence of a request indicates there is nowhere to store the value of this variable. Sometimes it's useful to test for the request if it's possible to execute the enclosing code block in an environment that may not run within a request or session. For instance, some batch server environments execute independent of a request.

        Returns:
        True if an HTTP request is currently in context, as tracked by the Guidewire platform. Otherwise false.
